    <dl>
           <dt>ga 1</dt>
           <dd><em>ga</em> (3rd consonant of the alphabet), the soft guttural having the sound <em>g</em> in <em>give</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of Ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; gak&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;ra</em> m. the letter <em>ga</em>. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p341-2"></a>[Page 341, Column 2]</font>
</dd>

           <dt>ga 2</dt>
           <dd><em>ga</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. (&#x221a;<em>gam</em>) only ifc. going, moving (e.g. <em>y&#x0101;na-</em>, going in a carriage <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> iv, 120 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> iii, 291 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;&#x012b;ghra-</em>, going quickly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> iii, 31, 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>antarik&#x1e63;a-</em> &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; having sexual intercourse with (cf. <em>anya-str&#x012b;-</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; reaching to (cf. <em>ka&#x1e47;&#x1e6d;ha-</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; staying, being, abiding in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;">VarB&#x1e5b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> iii, 13 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> &amp;c. (e.g. <em>pa&#x00f1;cama-</em>, abiding in or keeping the fifth place, &#x015a;rut.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; relating to or standing in connection with <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vi, 70, 59 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> &amp;c. (cf. <em>a-</em>, <em>agra-</em>, <em>a-jihma-</em>, <em>atyanta-</em>, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>agre-g&#x00e1;</em>, &amp;c.)</dd>

           <dt>ga 3</dt>
           <dd><em>ga</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-2, 8)n. (&#x221a;<em>gai</em>) only ifc. singing (cf. <em>chando-</em>, <em>pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;a-</em>, <em>s&#x0101;ma-</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a Gandharva or celestial musician <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a song <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), n. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>ga 4</dt>
           <dd><em>ga</em> (used in works on prosody as an abbreviation of the word <em>guru</em> to denote) a long syllable <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in music used as an abbreviation of the word <em>g&#x0101;ndh&#x0101;ra</em> to denote) the third note</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; 'Ganges-supporter', N. of &#x015a;iva (according to the legend the Ganges in its descent from heaven first alighted on the head of &#x015a;iva and continued for a long period entangled in his hair, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> R. i, ch. 44) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>ga&#x1e47;ayya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> [with <em>a-</em> neg., iv, 7, 15]), to count, number, enumerate, sum up, add up, reckon, take into account <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to think worth, value (with instr., e.g. <em>na ga&#x1e47;ay&#x0101;mi ta&#x1e43; t&#x1e5b;&#x1e47;ena</em>, 'I do not value him at a straw' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> ii, 1552) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to consider, regard as (with double acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> viii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; xi <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x012b;t">G&#x012b;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to enumerate among (loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 2603 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to ascribe, attribute to (loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhart&#x1e5b;">Bhart&#x1e5b;.</a> ii, 44 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to attend to, take notice of (acc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; often with <em>na</em>, not to care about, leave unnoticed) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to imagine, excogitate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> 107 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to count one's number (said of a flock or troop) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-3, 67 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ga&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>ga&#x1e47;&#x00e1;</em> m. a flock, troop, multitude, number, tribe, series, class (of animate or inanimate beings), body of followers or attendants <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; troops or classes of inferior deities (especially certain troops of demi-gods considered as &#x015a;iva's attendants and under the special superintendence of the god Ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>-devat&#x0101;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Lalit">Lalit.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a single attendant of &#x015a;iva         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> iii, 270 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; the 9 assemblies of &#x1e5a;ishis under the Arhat Mah&#x0101;-viira <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Jain">Jain.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a small body of troops (= 3 Gulmas or 27 chariots and as many elephants, 81 horses, and 135 foot) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 291 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a series or group of asterisms or lunar mansions classed under three heads (that of the gods, that of the men, and that of the R&#x0101;kshasas) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in arithm.) a number <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in metre) a foot or four instants (cf. <em>-cchandas</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in Gr.) a series of roots or words following the same rule and called after the first word of the series (e.g. <em>ad-&#x0101;di</em>, the g. <em>ad</em> &amp;c. or the whole series of roots of the 2nd class </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>garg&#x00e2;di</em>, the g. <em>garga</em> &amp;c. or the series of words commencing with <em>garga</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a particular group of S&#x0101;mans <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y">L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y.</a> i, 6, 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarYogay">VarYogay.</a> viii, 7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of perfume <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ga&#x1e47;e&#x015b;a </dt>
           <dd><em>ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a</em> m. (= <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e47;a-n&#x0101;tha</em>) N. of the god of wisdom and of obstacles (son of &#x015a;iva and P&#x0101;rvat&#x012b;, or according to one legend of P&#x0101;rvat&#x012b; alone </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; though Ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a causes obstacles he also removes them </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hence he is invoked at the commencement of all undertakings and at the opening of all compositions with the words <em>namo ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;&#x0101;ya vighn&#x00ea;&#x015b;var&#x0101;ya</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is represented as a short fat man with a protuberant belly, frequently riding on a rat or attended by one, and to denote his sagacity has the head of an elephant, which however has only one tusk </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the appellation Ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a, with other similar compounds, alludes to his office as chief of the various classes of subordinate gods, who are regarded as &#x015a;iva's attendants </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. pp. 48, 62, 79, 392, 440 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is said to have written down the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> as dictated by Vy&#x0101;sa <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 74 ff </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; persons possessed, by Ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a are referred to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> i, 270 ff.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 1629 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>ga&#x1e47;a-pu&#x1e43;gava</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;">VarB&#x1e5b;.</a> xiii, 8 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. pl. (= <em>vidy&#x00ea;&#x015b;a</em> or <em>&#x25cb;&#x015b;vara</em>) a class of Siddhas (with &#x015a;aivas) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> i, 11, 857 ff </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a renowned astronomer of the 16th century </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of R&#x0101;ma-deva (author of a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Comm">Comm.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nal&#x00f4;d">Nal&#x00f4;d.</a>) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p343-3"></a>[Page 343, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Vi&#x015b;van&#x0101;tha-d&#x012b;kshita and grandson of Bh&#x0101;var&#x0101;ma-k&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a (author of a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Comm">Comm.</a> called Ciccandrik&#x0101;) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kumbha</em> m. N. of a rocky cave in Orissa </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kusuma</em> m. a variety of oleander with red flowers <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of a section of the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#SkandaP">SkandaP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-bhuja&#x1e43;ga-pray&#x0101;tastotra</em> n. N. of a hymn in praise of Ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a (attributed to &#x015a;a&#x1e43;kar&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 5-4, 136) having only the smell of, containing only a very small quantity, bearing only the name of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vii, 24, 29</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; m. a seller of perfumes <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sulphur <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. v. l. for <em>gabdik&#x0101;</em> (N. of a country), q.v</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; smelling of (in comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> xv <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. having (only the smell, i.e.) a very little of anything <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a> vi, 38 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>m&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;-gandhin&#x012b;</em>, 'a mother only by name') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> ii, 75, 12 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for <em>gardhin</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> xii, 48 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), m. a bug, flying bug <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Xanthophyllum virens <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>in&#x012b;</em>), f. a kind of perfume <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>i</em>), n. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; gandhipar&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>gandhi-par&#x1e47;a</em> m. = &#x25cb;dha-p&#x25cb; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>gandholi</em> f. = <em>&#x25cb;dha-pal&#x0101;&#x015b;&#x012b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; gandhol&#x012b; </dt>
           <dd><em>gandhol&#x012b;</em> f. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Paederia foetida <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Cyperus rotundus <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; dried ginger <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (= <em>&#x25cb;dh&#x00e2;l&#x012b;</em>) a wasp <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Indr&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gal">Gal.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; gandhya </dt>
           <dd><em>gandhya</em> <em>v&#x0101;&#x0341;ja-g&#x25cb;</em>. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p346-1"></a>[Page 346, Column 1]</font>
</dd>

           <dt>gandharva </dt>
           <dd><em>gandharv&#x00e1;</em> m. a Gandharva [though in later times the Gandharvas are regarded as a class, yet in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> rarely more than one is mentioned </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is designated as the heavenly Gandharva (<em>divy&#x00e1; g&#x25cb;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 86, 36 and x, 139, 5), and is also called Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;-vasu (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 85, 21 and 22 ; 139, 4 and 5) and V&#x0101;yu-ke&#x015b;a (in pl. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iii, 38, 6) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his habitation is the sky, or the region of the air and the heavenly waters (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 22, 14 ; viii, 77, 5 ; ix, 85, 12 ; 86, 36 ; x, 10, 4 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> ii, 2, 3) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; his especial duty is to guard the heavenly Soma (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 83, 4 and 85, 12), which the gods obtain through his intervention (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vii, 73, 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RV. i, 22, 14) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is obtained for the human race by Indra, who conquers the Gandharva and takes it by force (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> viii, 1, 11 and 77, 5) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the heavenly Gandharva is supposed to be a good physician, because the Soma is considered as the best medicine </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; possibly, however, the word Soma originally denoted not the beverage so called, but the moon, and the heavenly Gandharva may have been the genius or tutelary deity of the moon </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in one passage (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 86, 36) the heavenly Gandharva and the Soma are identified </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is also regarded as one of the gen&#x012b; who regulate the course of the Sun's horses (i, 163, 2 ; x, 177, 2 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#135,">135,.</a> 5) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he knows and makes known the secrets of heaven and divine truths generally (x, 139, 5 and 6 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> ii, 1, 2 ; xx, 128, 3 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> xi, 1 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; xxxii, 9) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is the parent of the first pair of human beings, Yama and Yam&#x012b; (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 10, 4), and has a peculiar mystical power over women and a right to possess them (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 85, 21 and 22 ; 40 and 41) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for this reason he is invoked in marriage ceremonies (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xiv, 2, 35 and 36) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ecstatic states of mind and possession by evil spirits are supposed to be derived from the heavenly Gandharva (cf. <em>-g&#x1e5b;h&#x012b;ta</em>, <em>-graha</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Gandharvas as a class have the same characteristic features as the one Gandharva </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they live in the sky (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiv), guard the Soma (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 113, 3 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> iii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> i, 27), are governed by Varu&#x1e47;a (just as the Apsarasas are governed by Soma) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> x, 7, 3, know the best medicines (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> viii, 7, 23 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> xii, 98), regulate the course of the asterisms (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xiii, 1, 23 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> iv, 29, 21 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hence twenty-seven are mentioned <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> ix, 7), follow after women and are desirous of intercourse with them (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> iii) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; as soon as a girl becomes marriageable, she belongs to Soma, the Gandharvas, and Agni (cf. G&#x1e5b;ihy&#x0101;s. ii, 19 f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the wives of the Gandharvas are the Apsarasas (cf. <em>gandharv&#x00e2;psar&#x00e1;s</em>), and like them the Gandharvas are invoked in gambling with dice (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vii, 109, 5) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are also feared as evil beings together with the R&#x0101;kshasas, Kim&#x012b;dins, Pi&#x015b;&#x0101;cas, &amp;c., amulets being worn as a protection against them (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are said to have revealed the Vedas to V&#x0101;c (cf. &#x015a;Br. iii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;rG&#x1e5b;. ii, 12, 2), and are called the preceptors of the &#x1e5a;ishis (cf. &#x015a;Br. xi) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pur&#x016b;ravas is called among them (cf. ib.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in epic poetry the Gandharvas are the celestial musicians or heavenly singers (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 177, 2) who form the orchestra at the banquets of the gods, and they belong together with the Apsarasas to Indra's heaven, sharing also in his battles (cf. Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;. i, 71 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. p. 238) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the more systematic mythology the Gandharvas constitute one of the classes into which the higher creation is divided (i.e. gods, manes, Gandharvas <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xi, 5, 2 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or gods, Asuras, Gandharvas, men <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> vii, 8, 25, 2 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> &#x015a;Br. x </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or gods, men, Gandharvas, Apsarasas, Sarpas, and manes <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> iii, 31, 5 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for other enumerations <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> Nir. iii, 8 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> i, 37 [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> p. 237] &amp; iii, 196 ; vii, 23 ; xii, 47 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nal">Nal.</a> &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; divine and human Gandharvas are distinguished (cf. TUp. ii, 8 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the divine or Deva-Gandharvas are enumerated <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 2550 ff. and 4810 ff.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; another passage names 11 classes of Gandharvas (cf. T&#x0100;r. i, 9, 3) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the chief or leader of the Gandharvas is named Citra-ratha (cf. Bhag. x, 26) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are called the creatures of Praj&#x0101;pati (cf. Mn. i, 37) or of Brahm&#x0101; (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 11793) or of Ka&#x015b;yapa (11850) or of the Munis (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 2550 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 11553) or of Pr&#x0101;dh&#x0101; (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 2556) or of Arish&#x1e6d;&#x0101; (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 234 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> i, 21) or of V&#x0101;c (cf. PadmaP.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with Jainas the Gandharvas constitute one of the eight classes of the Vyantaras] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the attendant of the 17th Arhat of the present Avasarpi&#x1e47;&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a singer <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> lxxxvii, 33 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> i, 11, 21 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Ko&#x012b;0l or black cuckoo <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a sage, pious man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mah&#x012b;dh">Mah&#x012b;dh.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> xxxii, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a horse <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 11762 </dd>

           <dd><em>g&#x00e1;mbhi&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;ha</em> mfn. superl. of <em>gabh&#x012b;r&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> vii</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; gambh&#x012b;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>gambh&#x012b;r&#x00e1;</em> mfn. = <em>gabh&#x25cb;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (only in the beginning of P&#x0101;das, six times) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. (in post-Vedic writings <em>gambh&#x25cb;</em> is more used than <em>gabh&#x25cb;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the deepness of a man's navel, voice, and character are praised together <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> lxviii, 85 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hence a person who is said to have a deep navel, voice, and character is called <em>tri-g&#x25cb;</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iv, 254 ; v, 3939) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. (= <em>jambh&#x25cb;</em>) the lemon tree <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a Mantra of the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a hiccup, violent singultus (with <em>hikk&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a river <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> 41 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), n. 'depth', with <em>jamad-agne&#x1e25;</em>, N. of a S&#x0101;man</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; 2. sg. <em>gacch&#x0101;s</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vi, 35, 3] or <em>gacch&#x0101;si</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> v, 5, 6] </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; for &#x0100;. with prepositions, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 1-2, 13 ; 2nd fut. <em>gami&#x1e63;yati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. ; 1st fut. <em>g&#x00e1;nt&#x0101;</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-2, 58] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>jaganv&#x00e1;s</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c.] or <em>jagmivas</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-2, 68, f. <em>jagm&#x00fa;&#x1e63;&#x012b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p347-1"></a>[Page 347, Column 1]</font> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to go to or towards, approach (with acc. or loc. or dat. [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> ii, 15 ; xii, 7 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to go or pass (as time, e.g. <em>k&#x0101;le gacchati</em>, time going on, in the course of time) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to fall to the share of (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to go to any state or condition, undergo, partake of, participate in, receive, obtain (e.g. <em>mitrat&#x0101;&#x1e43; gacchati</em>, 'he goes to friendship', i.e. he becomes friendly) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>j&#x0101;nubhy&#x0101;m avan&#x012b;&#x1e43;-&#x221a;gam</em>, 'to go to the earth with the knees', kneel down <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xiii, 935 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> v, 1, 10/11 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>dhara&#x1e47;&#x012b;&#x1e43; m&#x016b;rdhn&#x0101;-&#x221a;gam</em>, 'to go to the earth with the head', make a bow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> iii, 11, 6 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x00e1;nas&#x0101;-&#x221a;gam</em>, to go with the mind, observe, perceive <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iii, 38, 6 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nal">Nal.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (without <em>m&#x00e1;nas&#x0101;</em>) to observe, understand, guess <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 2108 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (especially Pass. <em>gamyate</em>, 'to be understood or meant') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>do&#x1e63;e&#x1e47;a</em> or <em>do&#x1e63;ato-&#x221a;gam</em>, to approach with an accusation, ascribe guilt to a person (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 4322 and 7455 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> iv, 21, 3: Caus. <em>gamayati</em> (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 2-4, 46 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Impv. 2. sg. Ved. <em>gamay&#x0101;</em> or <em>g&#x0101;maya</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> v, 5, 10], 3. sg. <em>gamayat&#x0101;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> ii, 6 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; perf. <em>gamay&#x0101;&#x0341;&#x1e43; cak&#x0101;ra</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c.) to cause to go (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 60 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a>) or come, lead or conduct towards, send to (dat. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>), bring to a place (acc.            <dd>&#x2022; to cause to go to any condition, cause to become <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to impart, grant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xiv, 179 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; 'to let go', not care about <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> v, 10 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to excel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Prasannar">Prasannar.</a> i, 14 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to spend time <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to understand, make clear or intelligible, explain <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 11290 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (causal of the causal) to cause a person (acc.) to go by means of <em>jigami&#x1e63;ati</em> another <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-4, 52 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a>: Desid. <em>j&#x00ed;gami&#x1e63;ati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a>, or <em>jig&#x0101;&#x1e43;sate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-4, 16 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Siddh">Siddh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. (g. <em>vara&#x1e47;&#x00e2;di</em>) the city Gay&#x0101; (famous place of pilgrimage in Behar and residence of the saint Gaya </dd>

           <dt>garu&#x1e0d;a </dt>
           <dd><em>garu&#x1e0d;&#x00e1;</em> m. (&#x221a;2. <em>g&#x1e5d;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a> iv, 155, 'devourer', because Garu&#x1e0d;a was perhaps originally identified with the all-consuming fire of the sun's rays), N. of a mythical bird (chief of the feathered race, enemy of the serpent-race [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. p. 321], vehicle of Vish&#x1e47;u [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. pp. 65 ; 104 ; 288], son of Ka&#x015b;yapa and Vinat&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; shortly after his birth he frightened the gods by his brilliant lustre </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they supposed him to be Agni, and requested his protection </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; when they discovered that he was Garu&#x1e0d;a, they praised him as the highest being, and called him fire and sun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 1239 ff </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Aru&#x1e47;a, the charioteer of the sun or the personified dawn, is said to be the elder [or younger, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. p. 104] brother of Garu&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Sv&#x0101;h&#x0101;, the wife of Agni, takes the shape of a female Garu&#x1e0d;&#x012b; = <em>supar&#x1e47;&#x012b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 14307 and 14343) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Supar&#x1e47;">Supar&#x1e47;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0100;r">T&#x0100;r.</a> x, 1, 6 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a building shaped like Garu&#x1e0d;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a peculiar military array <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 187 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the attendant of the 16th Arhat of the present Avasarpi&#x1e47;&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the 14th Kalpa period </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a son of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 9196 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. of <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e0d;&#x00e1;</em>, q.v</dd>

           <dt>garbha </dt>
           <dd><em>g&#x00e1;rbha</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>grabh</em> = <em>grah</em>, 'to conceive' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; &#x221a;2. <em>g&#x1e5d;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a> iii, 152) the womb <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the inside, middle, interior of anything, calyx (as of a lotus) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> &amp;c. (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>, 'having in the interior, containing, filled with'         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RPr&#x0101;t">RPr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p349-3"></a>[Page 349, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an inner apartment, sleepingroom <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any interior chamber, adytum or sanctuary of a temple &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> p. 445 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a foetus or embryo, child, brood or offspring (of birds) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a woman's courses <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vish&#x1e47;">Vish&#x1e47;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'offspring of the sky', i.e. the fogs and vapour drawn upwards by the rays of the sun during eight months and sent down again in the rainy season (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ix, 305) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> iv, 27, 3 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> viii, 50 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the bed of a river (esp. of the Ganges) when fullest, i.e. on the fourteenth day of the dark half of the month Bh&#x0101;dra or in the height of the rains (the Garbha extends to this point, after which the T&#x012b;ra or proper bank begins, and extends for 150 cubits, this space being holy ground) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the situation in a drama when the complication of the plot has reached its height <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;ar">Da&#x015b;ar.</a> i, 36 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> vi, 68 and 79 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the rough coat of the Jaka fruit <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fire <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; joining, union <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a &#x1e5a;ishi (called Pr&#x0101;j&#x0101;patya) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h">K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; [cf. <em>am&#x1e5b;ta-</em>, <em>ardha-</em>, <em>k&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x1e47;a-</em>, <em>m&#x016b;&#x1e0d;ha-</em>, <em>vi&#x015b;va-</em>, <em>hira&#x1e47;ya-</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. also ? ; Hib. <em>cilfin</em>, 'the belly' ; Angl. Sax. <em>hrif</em> ; Germ. <em>kalb</em>: Engl. <em>calf</em>.]</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; [perf. <em>jig&#x0101;ya</em>, <em>ud-</em>], perf. Pot. <em>jag&#x0101;y&#x0101;t</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> ii, 14] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 28, 1 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to go away (from, abl </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to any place, loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 108, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to come to an end <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a> viii, 109 </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; g&#x0101;yatra </dt>
           <dd><em>g&#x0101;yatr&#x00e1;</em> m. n. a song, hymn <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> xi, 8 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> ii, 11, 1 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. a hymn composed in the G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; metre <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; metre <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> i, 5, 52 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a S&#x0101;man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> ix <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. consisting in or connected with the G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; (e.g. in accordance with the number of syllables of a G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; verse) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>vrata</em>, = <em>brahma-carya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> x, 45, 29 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. an ancient metre of twentyfour syllables (variously arranged, but generally as a triplet of eight syllables each), any hymn composed in the G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; metre <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 14 ; 16 &amp; 130, 4 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; (i.e. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iii, 62, 10 .; <em>t&#x00e1;t savit&#x00fa;r v&#x00e1;re&#x1e47;yam bh&#x00e1;rgo dev&#x00e1;sya dh&#x012b;mahi dh&#x00ed;yo y&#x00f3; na&#x1e25; pracod&#x00e1;y&#x00e2;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiv <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khG&#x1e5b;">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khG&#x1e5b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; this is a very sacred verse repeated by every Br&#x0101;hman at his morning and evening devotions </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; from being addressed to Savit&#x1e5b;i or the Sun as generator, it is also called S&#x0101;vitr&#x012b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. pp. 19 ; 342 ; 361 ; 403 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; verse is personified as a goddess, the wife of Brahm&#x0101; and mother of the four Vedas <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 11666 ff </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is often mentioned in connection with the Am&#x1e5b;ita, both together constituting as it were the essence and type of sacred hymns in general <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; personified is also considered as the mother of the first three classes in their capacity of twice-born <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. pp. 200 f </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; some other verse [perhaps <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 9, 1] is denoted by G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> vi, 28, 7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with T&#x0101;ntrikas a number of mystical verses are called G&#x0101;yatr&#x012b;s, and each deity has one in particular) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Durg&#x0101; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MatsyaP">MatsyaP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> liii, 172 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Acacia Catechu <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; speech, speaking, language, voice, words (e.g. <em>m&#x0101;nu&#x1e63;&#x012b;&#x1e43; gira&#x1e43;</em> &#x221a;1. <em>k&#x1e5b;</em>, to assume a human voice <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nal">Nal.</a> i, 25 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gir&#x0101;&#x1e43; prabhavi&#x1e63;&#x1e47;u&#x1e25;</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a>] or <em>pati</em> {cf. VarYogay.} = <em>gir-&#x012b;&#x015b;a</em>, q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>tad-gir&#x0101;</em>, on his advice <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> lxxv), OhUp. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>g&#x012b;r-devii</em>, fame, celebrity <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of mystical syllable <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;matUp">R&#x0101;matUp.</a> ; [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hib">Hib.</a> <em>gair</em>, 'an outcry, shout' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Gk. ?.] - 1</dd>

           <dt>gu&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>gu&#x1e47;&#x00e1;</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>grah</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a>) a single thread or strand of a cord or twine (e.g. <em>tri-g&#x25cb;</em>, q.v.), string or thread, rope <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> vii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kum">Kum.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a garland <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a bow-string <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> iii, 33, 16 (<em>c&#x0101;pa-</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> ix, 54 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x1e5a;itus">&#x1e5a;itus.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in geom.) a sinew </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the string of a musical instrument, chord <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> iv, 57: ifc. (f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) with numerals 'fold, times' ( <em>c&#x00e1;tur-</em>, <em>tri-</em>, <em>da&#x015b;a-</em>, <em>dv&#x00ed;-</em>, <em>pa&#x00f1;ca-</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rarely the numeral stands by itself along with <em>gu&#x1e47;&#x00e1;</em> [e.g. <em>vi&#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;o da&#x015b;abhir gu&#x1e47;ai&#x1e25;</em>, 'of ten times higher value' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ii, 85] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> x, 8, 43 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 15649 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 509 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; [<em>gu&#x1e47;a</em> = <em>bh&#x0101;ga</em>] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 5-2, 47 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a multiplier, co-efficient (in alg.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; subdivision, species, kind (e.g. <em>gandhasya gu&#x1e47;&#x0101;&#x1e25;</em>, the different kinds of smell <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xii, 6847) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the 6 subdivisions of action for a king in foreign politics (viz. peace, war, march, halt, stratagem, and recourse to the protection of a mightier king) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 160 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> i, 346 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> ii, 155 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>up&#x00e2;ya</em> (q.v., denoting the 4 ways of conquering an enemy) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> v, 81, 41 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'requisite', <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e47;&#x00f4;p&#x00ea;ta</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a secondary element, subordinate or unessential part of any action (e.g. <em>sarva-g&#x25cb;</em> mfn. 'reaching to all subordinate parts', hence 'valid throughout' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> v, 1, 71 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an auxiliary act <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr.</a> xxvi, 4 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a secondary dish (opposed to <em>anna</em> i.e. rice or the chief dish), side-dish <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> iii, 224 ff </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (= <em>-karman</em>, in Gr.) the secondary or less immediate object of an action <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-4, 51 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a quality, peculiarity, attribute or property <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y">L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khG&#x1e5b;">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khG&#x1e5b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> iii, ix, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an attribute of the 5 elements (each of which has its own peculiar quality or qualities as well as organ of sense </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; thus 1. ether has <em>&#x015b;abda</em>, or sound for its Gu&#x1e47;a and the ear for its organ </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. the air has tangibility and sound for its Gu&#x1e47;as and the skin for its organ </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. fire or light has shape or colour, tangibility, and sound for its Gu&#x1e47;as, and the eye for its organs </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 4. water has flavour, shape, tangibility, and sound for its Gu&#x1e47;as, and the tongue for its organ </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 5. earth has the preceding Gu&#x1e47;as, with the addition of its own peculiar Gu&#x1e47;a of smell, and the nose for its organ) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> i, 20 and 76-78 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xii, 6846 ff. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> i, 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> iii, 5, 35 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in &#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e43;khya phil.) an ingredient or constituent of Prak&#x1e5b;iti, chief quality of all existing beings (viz. <em>sattva</em>, <em>rajas</em>, and <em>tamas</em> i.e. goodness, passion, and darkness, or virtue, foulness, and ignorance </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> RTL. pp. 31 ; 36 ; 163) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> i ; iii, 40 ; xii, 24 ff. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak">S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhag">Bhag.</a> xiii f </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (hence) the number 'three' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> &#x012b;c, 1 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a property or characteristic of all created things (in Ny&#x0101;ya phil. twenty-four Gu&#x1e47;as are enumerated, viz. 1. <em>r&#x016b;pa</em>, shape, colour </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. <em>rasa</em>, savour </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. <em>gandha</em>, odour </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 4. <em>spar&#x015b;a</em>, tangibility </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 5. <em>sa&#x1e43;khy&#x0101;</em>, number </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 6. <em>parim&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em>, dimension </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 7. <em>p&#x1e5b;thaktva</em>, severalty </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 8. <em>sa&#x1e43;yoga</em>, conjunction </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 9. <em>vibh&#x0101;ga</em>, disjunction </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 10. <em>paratva</em>, remoteness </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 11. <em>aparatva</em>, proximity </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 12. <em>gurutva</em>, weight </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 13. <em>dravatva</em>, fluidity </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 14. <em>sneha</em>, viscidity </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 15. <em>&#x015b;abda</em>, sound </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 16. <em>buddhi</em> or <em>j&#x00f1;&#x0101;na</em>, understanding or knowledge </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 17. <em>sukha</em>, pleasure </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 18. <em>du&#x1e25;kha</em>, pain </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 19. <em>icch&#x0101;</em>, desire ; 20. <em>dve&#x1e63;a</em>, aversion ; 21. <em>prayatna</em>, effort ; 22. <em>dharma</em>, merit or virtue ; 23. <em>adharma</em>, demerit ; 24. <em>sa&#x1e43;sk&#x0101;ra</em>, the self-reproductive quality) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an epithet <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; good quality, virtue, merit, excellence <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the merit of composition (consistency, elegance of expression, &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d">K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d.</a> i, 41 f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kpr">Kpr.</a> viii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> viii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the peculiar properties of the letters (11 in number, viz. the 8 <em>b&#x0101;hya-prayatn&#x0101;s</em> <em>q.v.</em> and the 3 accents) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-1, 9 and 50 (cf. <em>-m&#x0101;tra</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the first gradation of a vowel, the vowels <em>a</em> (with <em>ar</em>, <em>al</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-1, 51), <em>e</em>, <em>o</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> x, 17 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RPr&#x0101;t">RPr&#x0101;t.</a> xi, 6 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an organ of sense <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a cook (cf. <em>-k&#x0101;ra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Bh&#x012b;ma-sena (cf. <em>-k&#x0101;ra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. Sanseviera Roxburghiana <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the plant <em>m&#x0101;&#x1e43;sarohi&#x1e47;&#x012b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a princess <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> iv, 695 (cf. <em>nir-</em>, <em>vi-</em>, <em>sa-</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gau&#x1e47;a</em>.)</dd>

           <dt>go </dt>
           <dd><em>g&#x00f3;</em> <em>ga&#x00fa;s</em> (acc. <em>g&#x0101;&#x0341;m</em> instr. <em>g&#x00e1;v&#x0101;</em> dat. <em>g&#x00e1;ve</em>, gen. abl. <em>g&#x00f3;s</em> loc. <em>g&#x00e1;vi</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; du. <em>g&#x0101;&#x0341;v&#x0101;</em> <em>Ved.</em>, <em>g&#x0101;&#x0341;vau</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. nom. <em>g&#x0101;&#x0341;vas</em> acc. <em>g&#x0101;&#x0341;s</em> [rarely <em>g&#x0101;&#x0341;vas</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> iii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TUp">TUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iv, 1506 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &#x012b;], instr. <em>g&#x00f3;bhis</em> dat. abl. <em>g&#x00f3;bhyas</em>, gen. <em>g&#x00e1;v&#x0101;m</em> [once at the end of a P&#x0101;da <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iv, 1, 19] and [in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> at the end of P&#x0101;das only, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 7-1, 57] <em>g&#x00f3;n&#x0101;m</em> loc. <em>g&#x00f3;&#x1e63;u</em>), m. an ox, f. a cow, (pl.) cattle, kine, herd of cattle <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. (in comp. before vowels [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 6-1, 122 ff.] <em>gav</em>, <em>gava</em>, qq. vv </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. also <em>gav&#x0101;m</em>, <em>gavi</em>, <em>g&#x0101;&#x1e43;</em> ss.vv </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gav&#x0101;&#x1e43; vrata</em>, N. of a S&#x0101;man </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gav&#x0101;&#x1e43; t&#x012b;rtha</em>, <em>go t&#x25cb;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>g&#x00f3;&#x1e63;u-&#x221a;gam</em>, to set out for a battle <em>to conquer cows</em> cf. RV. ii, 25, 4 ; v, 45, 9 ; viii, 71, 5) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'anything coming from or belonging to an ox or cow', milk (generally pl.), flesh (only pl. cf. RV. x, 16, 7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'fat' cf. Gmn.), skin, hide, leather, strap of leather, bow-string, sinew (cf. RV. x, 27, 22 cf. AV. i, 2, 3) cf. RV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>g&#x00f3;-&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;oma</em> (q.v.) cf. AitBr. iv, 15 cf. &#x015a;Br. xiii ( also <em>go-&#x0101;y&#x00fa;s</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) 'the herds of the sky', the stars cf. RV. i, 154, 6 and vii, 36, 1 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (m. <em>also f. cf. &#x016b;&#x1e47;. cf. &#x1e63;ch.</em>) rays of light (regarded as the herds of the sky, for which Indra fights with V&#x1e5b;itra) cf. MBh. i, iii cf. Hariv. 2943 cf. R. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. the sign Taurus cf. VarB&#x1e5b;S. xl f. cf. VarB&#x1e5b;. cf. Laghuj </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the sun (cf. <em>-putra</em>) cf. Nir. ii, 6 and 14 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the moon cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of medicinal plant (<em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;abha</em>) cf. L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a singer, praiser (fr. &#x221a;<em>gai</em>) cf. Naigh. iii, 16 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'a goer', horse (fr. &#x221a;1. <em>g&#x0101;</em>) cf. S&#x0101;y. on cf. RV. i, 121, 9 and iv, 22, 8 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of two &#x1e5a;ishis of the cf. SV. (with the patr. &#x0100;&#x1e45;girasa [cf. T&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;yaBr. xvi] and M&#x0101;y&#x016b;ka) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a man (who with Pushkara is said to be the <em>bal&#x00e2;dhyak&#x1e63;a</em> of the sons and grandsons of Varu&#x1e47;a) cf. MBh. ii, 381 (cf. cf. R. vii, 23, 28) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. or f. (?) the sun's ray called Sushum&#x1e47;a cf. Nir. ii, 6 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; water cf. BhP. i, 10, 36 (also f. pl., xi, 7, 50) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an organ of sense cf. BhP. vii, 5, 30 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the eye cf. Kuval. 70 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a billion cf. T&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;yaBr. xvii, 14, 2 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; the thunderbolt cf. S&#x0101;y. on cf. RV. v, 30, 7 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (cf. Naigh. i, 1) the earth (as the milk-cow of kings) cf. Mn. iv, xii cf. MBh. cf. R. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (hence) the number 'nine' cf. Jyot. cf. S&#x016b;ryas </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>go-viith&#x012b;</em> cf. Sch. on cf. VarB&#x1e5b;S. ix, 1 ff </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a mother cf. L. (cf. cf. VarB&#x1e5b;S. iii, 68) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (cf. Naigh. i, 11) speech, Sarasvat&#x012b; (goddess of speech) cf. MBh. i, iii, v cf. Ragh. ii, v cf. C&#x0101;&#x1e47; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; voice, note (fr. &#x221a;<em>gai</em>) cf. &#x015a;i&#x015b;. iv, 36 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Gaur&#x012b; cf. Gal </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the wife [or of a daughter-in-law cf. BhP. ix, 21, 25] of &#x015a;uka (a daughter of the manes called Suk&#x0101;las) cf. Hariv. 986 cf. MatsyaP </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a daughter of Kakut-stha and wife of Yay&#x0101;ti cf. Hariv. 1601 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; [cf. ? ; Lat. <em>bos</em> ; Old Germ. <em>chuo</em> ; Mod. Germ. <em>Kuh</em> ; Eng. <em>cow</em> ; Lett. <em>gohw</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; subordinate, secondary, unessential <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xii, xiii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#KapS">KapS.</a> &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; metaphorical, figurative <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;&#x0341;</em>), f. the female of the Bos Gaurus <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ('V&#x0101;c or voice of the middle region of the air', i, 164, 41 according to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> i, 11 and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> xi, 40) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (in astron.) to calculate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x016b;ryas">S&#x016b;ryas.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to accept, admit, approve <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> i, 6299 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> ii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> ix, 18 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;d">K&#x0101;d.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> i, 2, 12 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to obey, follow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> ix, 30/31 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> iii f </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to take for, consider as <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> i, 110 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;lav">M&#x0101;lav.</a> v &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (Pass.) to be meant by (instr.)         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Siddh">Siddh.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>: Caus. <em>gr&#x0101;hayati</em>, to cause to take or seize or lay hold of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> xv, 88 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to take (by the hand [<em>p&#x0101;&#x1e47;im</em>] in the marriage ceremony) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> xvii, 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to marry, give away a girl (acc.) in marriage to any one (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kum">Kum.</a> i, 53 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause any one to be captured <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> ii, 169 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vi, 1, 21 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause any one to be seized or overpowered (as by Varu&#x1e47;a's punishments or death &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> ii, vi f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> i <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> viii, 3281 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to be taken away <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to make any one take, deliver anything (acc.) over to any one (acc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; e.g. <em>&#x0101;sanam</em> with acc.            <dd>&#x2022; to make any one choose <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> v, 102 (aor. <em>ajigrahat</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to make any one learn, make acquainted or familiar with (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> i, 4 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;p">&#x0100;p.</a> i, 8, 25 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> i, 58 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Desid. <em>jigh&#x1e5b;k&#x1e63;ati</em> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-2, 8 &amp; vii, 2, 12), also <em>&#x25cb;te</em>, to be about to seize or take <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gobh">Gobh.</a> i, 1, 8 and 20 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be about to eclipse <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vii, 35, 31 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be about to take away <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> i, 17, 25 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to desire to perceive (with the organs of sense), strive to apprehend or recognise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitUp">AitUp.</a> iii, 3 ff. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> ii, iv: Intens. <em>jar&#x012b;g&#x1e5b;hyate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-1, 16 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> [372, 1] ; [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Zd">Zd.</a> <em>gerep</em>, <em>geurv</em> ; Goth. <em>greipa</em> ; Germ. <em>greife</em> ; Lith. <em>gre1bju</em> ; Slav. <em>grablj&#x016b;</em> ; Hib. <em>grabaim</em>, 'I devour, stop.']</dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;vat</em> (<em>gr&#x00e1;bh&#x25cb;</em>), mfn. yielding any hold or support <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 127, 5</dd>

           <dd><em>gr&#x00e1;bh&#x012b;t&#x1e5b;</em> mfn. one who seizes <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> i, 12, 2</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; graha </dt>
           <dd><em>gr&#x00e1;ha</em> (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-3, 58 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; g. <em>v&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x00e2;di</em>), mfn. ifc. (iii, 2, 9 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 1) seizing, laying hold of, holding <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> iii, 15, 35 (cf. <em>a&#x1e45;ku&#x015b;a-</em>, <em>dhanur-</em>, &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; obtaining, v, viii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; perceiving, recognising, iv, 7, 31 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. 'seizer (eclipser)', R&#x0101;hu or the dragon's head <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a planet (as seizing or influencing the destinies of men in a supernatural manner </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes 5 are enumerated, viz. Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, and Saturn <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> vi, 4566 f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> i, 19, 2 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> iii, 13 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also 7, i.e. the preceding with R&#x0101;hu and Ketu <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> vii, 5636 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also 9, i.e. the sun [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> &#x015a;Br. iv, 6, 5, 1 and 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xiii, 913 ; xiv, 1175] and moon with the 7 preceding <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> i, 295 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iv, 48 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also the polar star is called a Graha, Garg. (cf. Jyot. 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the planets are either auspicious <em>&#x015b;ubha-</em>, <em>sad-</em>, or inauspicious <em>kr&#x016b;ra-</em>, <em>p&#x0101;pa-</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with Jainas they constitute one of the 5 classes of the Jyotishkas) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the place of a planet in the fixed zodiac <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the number 'nine' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of particular evil demons or spirits who seize or exercise a bad influence on the body and mind of man (causing insanity &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it falls within the province of medical science to expel these demons </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; those who esp. seize children and cause convulsions &amp;c. are divided into 9 classes according to the number of planets <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any state which proceeds from magical influences and takes possession of the whole man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> vii, ix <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BrahmaP">BrahmaP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> ii, 1, 20 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a crocodile <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xvi, 142 (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> iv f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> viii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any ladle or vessel employed for taking up a portion of fluid (esp. of Soma) out of a larger vessel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> v, 116 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> i, 182 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the 8 organs of perception (viz. the 5 organs of sense with Manas, the hands and the voice) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiv <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#N&#x1e5b;isUp">N&#x1e5b;isUp.</a> i, 4, 3, 22 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (= <em>g&#x1e5b;ha</em>) a house <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vii, 40, 30 (cf. <em>a-</em>, <em>khara-</em>, <em>-druma</em> and <em>-pati</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'anything seized', spoil, booty <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 11461 (cf. <em>&#x25cb;h&#x00e2;lu&#x00f1;cana</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; as much as can be taken with a ladle or spoon out of a larger vessel, ladleful, spoonful (esp. of Soma) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 114, 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the middle of a bow or that part which is grasped when the bow is used <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iv, 1351 (<em>su-</em>, 1326) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the beginning of any piece of music </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; grasp, seizing, laying hold of (often ifc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kau&#x015b;">Kau&#x015b;.</a> 10 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; keeping back, obstructing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; imprisoning, imprisonment (<em>&#x25cb;ha&#x1e43;-&#x221a;gam</em>, 'to become a prisoner' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;m">K&#x0101;m.</a>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> ii, 58, 2 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; seizure (by demons causing diseases, e.g. <em>a&#x1e45;ga-</em>, spasm of the limbs) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; seizure of the sun and moon, eclipse <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xix, 9, 7 and 10 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; stealing, robbing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ix, 277 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> vi, 4458 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; effort <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; insisting upon, tenacity, perseverance in (loc. or in comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> vii, 14, 11 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a> ix, 12 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> viii, 226 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; taking, receiving, reception <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> viii, 180 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x1e5b;i&#x1e45;g&#x0101;r">&#x015a;&#x1e5b;i&#x1e45;g&#x0101;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; taking up (any fluid) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; choosing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> xii, 83, 12 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> vi, 136 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'favour', <em>-nigraha</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; mentioning, employing (a word) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> viii, 271 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-1, 21, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;r">K&#x0101;r.</a> 2 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Amar">Amar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; apprehension, perception, understanding <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bh&#x0101;sh&#x0101;p">Bh&#x0101;sh&#x0101;p.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Jaim">Jaim.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#KapS">KapS.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;ya</em>), dat. ind. = <em>g&#x1e5b;h&#x012b;tv&#x0101;</em>, &#x221a;<em>grah</em> (cf. <em>guda-</em>, <em>&#x015b;iro-</em>, <em>hanu-</em>, <em>h&#x1e5b;d-</em>.)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; mentioning, employing (a word or expression) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y">L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y.</a>         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VPr&#x0101;t">VPr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> vi, 205 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; acceptation, meaning <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-1, 68 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 5 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Siddh">Siddh.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. an imaginary organ supposed to lie between the stomach and the intestines (the small intestines or that part of the alimentary canal where the bile assists digestion and from which vital warmth is said to be diffused) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e47;&#x012b;-gada</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ash&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;&#x1e45;g">Ash&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;&#x1e45;g.</a> iii, 8 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> i, 7 (cf. <em>kara-</em>, <em>ke&#x015b;a-</em>, <em>garbha-</em>, <em>cak&#x1e63;ur-</em>, <em>n&#x0101;ma-</em>, <em>p&#x0101;&#x1e47;i-</em>, <em>punar-</em>.)</dd>
